metadata.case_name: Dr. K.C. Nambiar v. State of Madras & Ors.

facts.text: The Legislature of the State of Madras enacted the Madras Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1960.

Section 4 of the Act provides that the Controller shall, on application by the tenant or landlord, fix fair rent for a building in accordance with principles in sub-section (2) or (3) and other prescribed principles.

For non-residential buildings, fair rent is 9% gross return per annum on total cost, consisting of: (i) cost of construction less depreciation, (ii) market value of site portion, (iii) allowances not exceeding 25% of cost of construction for locality, amenities etc.
Section 34 confers power on State Government to make rules.
State Government published rules; Rules 11-14 deal with classification of non-residential buildings, cost of construction, allowances for amenities, depreciation.
Rule 11: Non-residential buildings classified into factories/godowns and others; others into four classes per Rule 8 for residential.
Rule 12: Cost of construction rates specified, e.g., factories/godowns 62 naye paise per cubic foot; classes I-IV at specified rates per sq ft plinth area.
Rule 13: Allowances for amenities like air-conditioning, lifts, etc. in addition to S.4(3).
Dr. K.C. Nambiar is tenant of 2/137, Purasawalkam High Road, Madras at monthly rental of Rs. 187.50, conducts nursing home.
Landlord applied to Controller to fix fair rent at Rs. 2,575 per month.
Dr. Nambiar applied to Madras High Court for writ of prohibition against Controller, pleading rules under S.4 invalid as inconsistent with Act.
Single Judge dismissed petition along with others challenging rules.
High Court dismissed Writ Appeal No. 356 of 1964 on August 6, 1965.
Dr. Nambiar appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rules framed by State Government under S.4 are invalid as inconsistent with the Act, particularly interpretation of 'cost of construction' in S.4(3)(b)(i) â€“ original cost or cost of reproducing similar building at date of Act.
Whether Rule 12 prescribing rates for cost of construction exceeds the terms of S.4(3)(b)(i).

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'cost of construction' in S.4(3) means cost of original construction and subsequent additions; landlord not entitled to fair rent on basis of cost to reproduce similar building at date of application or Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(3)(b)(i) of Madras Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1960

petitioner_arguments.text: Rules inconsistent with intention and ambit of Act and invalid.
P.W.D. rates available to determine original cost of construction.

respondent_arguments.text: 'Cost of construction' means cost of reproducing similar building at date Act brought into force; deduct depreciation per rules to arrive at market value of structure.
S.4(2)(b)(i) provides cost of construction according to prescribed rates, not actual cost; statutory rate unrelated to actual investment.
Allowances for locality etc. as on date Act came into force.
For old buildings, original cost may not be ascertainable.

court_reasoning.text: Legislature used 'cost of construction' in S.4(3)(b)(i) and 'market value' in (b)(ii); difficult to accept same meaning; cost means amount originally expended, not market value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Cost of construction' denotes not the market value but the cost of the original construction.

court_reasoning.text: Total cost includes allowances for site advantages separately from cost of construction; if cost of construction meant market value, it would duplicate allowances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amenities included in allowances under (iii) would be double-counted if part of market value in (i).

court_reasoning.text: Prescribed rates reverse normal depreciation process; cost of construction is artificial value related to date of Act, neither original nor current market value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule 12 prescribes fixed rates, but statute does not warrant reproduction cost.

court_reasoning.text: Prescribing rates without guidance is excessive delegation; but State claimed rates were prevailing in 1961.
Rent restriction laws peg rent to original cost, denying unearned increment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Depreciation per Sch. II ensures fair return without current value.

court_reasoning.text: If 'cost of construction' means original cost, Rule 12 prescribing rates plainly exceeds section.

holdings.text: 'Cost of construction' in S.4(3)(b)(i) means cost of original construction with subsequent additions, not reproduction cost at date of Act.
Rules 11-14, particularly Rule 12, exceed terms of S.4 and are invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs fixation of fair rent; 'cost of construction' interpreted as original cost; rules under S.34 invalid as exceeding S.4.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dismissing writ petition set aside; Controller directed to determine fair rent per Act provisions uninfluenced by rules; appellant entitled to costs in SC and High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of prohibition issued; rules held invalid for this purpose.
outcome.costs: Appellant entitled to costs in this Court and the High Court.

key_quotes.text: 'Cost of construction' in sub-s. 3(b)(i) ... is ... used to denote not the market value but the cost of the original construction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of key phrase.

key_quotes.text: If the expression 'cost of construction' in sub-s. (3)(b)(i) means the cost of construction of the building as originally erected ... r. 12 ... plainly goes beyond the terms of the section.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The appeal is allowed. The order dismissing the petition is discharged.
key_quotes.speaker: court
